fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We fix \mathbb {Z} := {{(\mathbb {N} \times \mathbb {N})}_{/{\sim }}} where (a,b) \sim (c,d) if and only if a + d = b + c.
Two sets are equal iff they have the same elements.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,y.\mkern 5mux = y \Leftrightarrow \forall z.\mkern 5muz \in x \Leftrightarrow z \in y

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The empty set \varnothing exists.
For any two set x and y, the set \{x,y\} exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,y.\mkern 5mu\exists p.\mkern 5mu\forall z.\mkern 5muz \in p \Leftrightarrow z = x \vee z = y

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \varphi be any formula in the language of ZF set theory with free variables among x, z, p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n} and x be a set. The set {\mathopen {}\{z \in X\colon \varphi (x,p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n},z)\}\mathclose {}} exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n}.\mkern 5mu\exists y.\mkern 5mu\forall z.\mkern 5muz \in y \Leftrightarrow z \in x \wedge \varphi (x,p_{1},\ldots ,p_{n},z)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any set x, the powerset P(x) is a set.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x.\mkern 5mu\exists p.\mkern 5mu\forall y.\mkern 5muy \in p \Leftrightarrow \forall z.\mkern 5muz \in y \Rightarrow z \in x

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a set x (of sets), the union \bigcup x exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x.\mkern 5mu\exists y.\mkern 5mu\forall z.\mkern 5muz \in y \Leftrightarrow \exists v.\mkern 5muv \in x \wedge z \in v

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An inductive set exists.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \exists x.\mkern 5mu\varnothing \in x \wedge \forall y.\mkern 5muy \in x \Rightarrow y \cup \{y\} \in x

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The image of every definable function is a set.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: (\forall x.\mkern 5mu\exists y.\mkern 5mu\varphi (x,y)) \wedge (\forall x,y,y'.\mkern 5mu\varphi (x,y) \wedge \varphi (x,y') \Rightarrow y = y') \Rightarrow \\ \forall u.\mkern 5mu\exists v.\mkern 5mu\forall y.\mkern 5muy \in v \Leftrightarrow \exists x.\mkern 5mux \in u \Rightarrow \varphi (x,y)

fr:p.fr:tex: \forall x.\mkern 5mu(\exists y.\mkern 5muy \in x) \Rightarrow \exists z.\mkern 5muz \in x \wedge (\lnot \exists a.\mkern 5mua \in x \wedge a \in z)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The empty set \varnothing is unique.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let E be a set such that \forall y.\mkern 5muy \notin E. By extensionality, it suffices to show that \forall y.\mkern 5muy \in \varnothing \Leftrightarrow y \in E, but this holds vacuously.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x,y be sets. Then the set {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} is unique.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Let P be a set such that \forall a.\mkern 5mua \in P \Leftrightarrow a = x \vee a = y. It suffices, by extensionality, to show that \forall b.\mkern 5mub \in {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} \Leftrightarrow b \in P.
If b \in {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}}, then by pairing, b = x or b = y. Thus, it follows that b \in P. The converse is completely analogous.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any set x, the set {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} exists.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By pairing, there is a set p such that \forall a.\mkern 5mua \in p \Leftrightarrow a = x \vee a = x, or equivalently, \forall a.\mkern 5mua \in p \Leftrightarrow a = x.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any set x, x \notin x.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let x be a set. Suppose that x \in x. Consider {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}}. This is a non-empty set, so foundation implies that there is a set z \in {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} such that z \cap {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} = \varnothing . By , z = x. Then since x \in x, we have that x \in z. Thus, x \in z \cap {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}}, which is a contradiction.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x,y be sets. We define the ordered pair (x,y) as the set {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}}.
Let x,y be sets. The ordered pair (x,y) exists.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} exists. By pairing, {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} exists. By pairing again, {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}} exists.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x,y,a,b be sets. Then (x,y) = (a,b) if and only if x = a and y = b.

The only if direction is completely trivial. Only the if direction remains. Assume that (x,y) = (a,b). First, we claim that x = a. By definition, we have {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}}. By extensionality, {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} \in {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}}. By pairing, either {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}} or {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}. In the former case, x = a follows as a consequence of pairing. In the latter case, we have a \in {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} and b \in {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} as a consequence of extensionality. Then by pairing, we have x = a = b.

It remains to show that y = b. In this case, as a consequence of extensionality, consider {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} \in {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}}. By pairing, either {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}} or {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}. In the former case, we have x = y = a as a consequence of extensionality and pairing. Thus, {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}} demands that a = b. In the latter case, if y = a then {\mathopen {}\{x,y\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a,y\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}} demands that a = b. But, if y = b then there is nothing left to prove.
Let A,B be sets. Then A \times B := {\mathopen {}\{(a,b)\colon a \in A \wedge b \in B\}\mathclose {}} is a set.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let a \in A, b \in B. By definition, (a,b) = {\mathopen {}\{{\mathopen {}\{a\}\mathclose {}},{\mathopen {}\{a,b\}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}}. Thus, by the powerset axiom, (a,b) \in \mathcal {P}(\mathcal {P}(A \cup B)). By separation, A \times B = {\mathopen {}\{p \in \mathcal {P}(\mathcal {P}(A \cup B))\colon \exists a.\mkern 5mu\exists b.\mkern 5mup = (a,b)\}\mathclose {}} is a set.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (binary) relation R\colon A\nrightarrow B is a subset R \subseteq A \times B. Its left support is the set \mathsf {lsupp}(R) := {\mathopen {}\{a \in A\colon \exists b \in B.\mkern 5mu(a,b) \in R\}\mathclose {}} and its range is the set \mathsf {ran}(R) := {\mathopen {}\{b \in B\colon \exists a \in A.\mkern 5mu(a,b) \in R\}\mathclose {}}. Its support is the set \mathsf {supp}(R) := \mathsf {lsupp}(R) \cup \mathsf {ran}(R) \subseteq A \cup B.
A relation R\colon A\nrightarrow B is total if \mathsf {lsupp}(R) = A. In other words, for all a \in A there exists b \in B such that (a,b) \in R.
A relation R\colon A\nrightarrow B is functional if for any (a,b),(c,d) \in R if a = c then b = d.
A relation R\colon A\nrightarrow B is injective if for every (a,b),(c,d) \in R if b = d then a = c.
A relation R\colon A\nrightarrow B is surjective if \mathsf {ran}(R) = B. In other words, for every b \in B there is a \in A such that (a,b) \in R.

A function f\colon A\to B is a total and functional relation f\colon A\nrightarrow B. We define B^{A} := {\mathopen {}\{f \in \mathcal {P}(A \times B)\colon \text {$f$ is a function}\}\mathclose {}}. For the purpose of this course, we do not require functions to have a specified codomain.
Let f,g be functions with domain A. Then f = g if and only if for all a \in A, f(a) = g(a).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The if direction is trivial. For the only if direction, assume that f(a) = g(a) for all a \in A. By extensionality, it suffices to show that (a,b) \in f if and only if (a,b) \in g. Suppose that (a,b) \in f, then by functionality, b = f(a). By totality, (a,g(a)) \in g. By hypothesis, (a,f(a)) = (a,g(a)). Thus, (a,f(a)) \in g. The converse is analogous.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F be a binary definable mapping with x,y free. Then for any set A, there is a function f with \mathsf {dom}(f) = A such that f(a) = b \Leftrightarrow F{\mathopen {}[a/x,b/y]\mathclose {}}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By replacement, \mathsf {ran}(F) := {\mathopen {}\{b\colon \exists a \in A.\mkern 5muF(a,b)\}\mathclose {}} is a set. Then we can define f by separation f := {\mathopen {}\{(a,b) \in A \times \mathsf {ran}(F)\colon F(a,b)\}\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \sim \colon X\nrightarrow X be an equivalence relation. A function f\colon X^{n}\to Y is congruent on \sim if for any a_{i} \sim b_{i}, f(a_{1},\ldots ,a_{n}) = f(b_{1},\ldots ,b_{n}). Similarly, a relation R\colon X^{n}\nrightarrow X^{n} is congruent on \sim if for any a_{i} \sim b_{i}, we have (a_{1},\ldots ,a_{n}) \in R if and only if (b_{1},\ldots ,b_{n}) \in R.

fr:title.text: Congruent functions induce functions on equivalence classes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Congruent functions induce functions on equivalence classes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \sim \colon X\nrightarrow X be an equivalence relation and f\colon X^{n}\to Y be a congruence on \sim . Then g := {\mathopen {}\{({\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}},y) \in ({{X}_{/{\sim }}})^{n} \times Y\colon f(x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}) = y\}\mathclose {}} is a function.

For any {\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}} \in {{X}_{/{\sim }}}, there is some y \in Y such that f(x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}) = y since f is a function. Thus, ({\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}}, y) \in g.

Suppose that ({\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}},y), ({\mathopen {}[x_{1}']\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}']\mathclose {}},y') \in g where x_{i} \sim x_{i}'. Then since f is a congruence, y = y'.
Let N be a natural number set. Then for any n \in N, s(n) \neq n.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Consider the subset P := {\mathopen {}\{x \in N\colon s(x) 
eq x\}\mathclose {}}. By the induction principle, it suffices to show that 0 \in P and for any x \in N, if x \in P then s(x) \in P. First, 0 \in P follows from the non-looping property. Now assume that x \in P, i.e., s(x) 
eq x. Then if s(s(x)) = s(x), by injectivity, s(x) = x, which is a contradiction. Thus, s(s(x)) 
eq s(x). In other words, s(x) \in P.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let N be an inductive set admitting the induction principle defined in natural number set. For each n \in N, we define s(n) := n \cup {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}. Then for any m,n \in N, if m \in n then s(m) \in s(n).
Fix m \in N. Consider P := {\mathopen {}\{n \in N\colon m \in n \Rightarrow s(m) \in s(n)\}\mathclose {}}. Note that \varnothing \in P vacuously.

Now let n \in P, i.e., m \in n \Rightarrow s(m) \in s(n). We need to show that s(n) \in P, i.e., m \in s(n) \Rightarrow s(m) \in s(s(n)). Suppose that m \in s(n) = n \cup {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}. By union, m \in n or m \in {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}. In the former case, we have s(m) \in s(n) \subseteq s(n) \cup {\mathopen {}\{s(n)\}\mathclose {}} = s(s(n)). In the latter case, we have m = n by . Then s(m) = s(n) \in s(n) \cup {\mathopen {}\{s(n)\}\mathclose {}} = s(s(n)).

Let I be the inductive set guaranteed by infinity. Define \mathbb {N} := \bigcap {\mathopen {}\{S \in \mathcal {P}(I)\colon \text {$S$ is inductive}\}\mathclose {}}. For this construction to work, we must show that \mathbb {N} is inductive.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, every inductive set S contains \varnothing . Thus, it follows that \varnothing \in \mathbb {N}. Now for any x \in \mathbb {N}, we have x \in S for any inductive set S \subseteq I. Thus, x \cup {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} is an element of every inductive subset of I. Then it follows that x \cup {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} \in \mathbb {N}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We take 0 := \varnothing \in \mathbb {N} and we define s\colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} by s(x) = x \cup {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}}. It remains to show that \mathbb {N} is a natural number set.
First, we prove the non-looping property. Observe that s(\varnothing ) = \varnothing \cup {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}} \neq \varnothing .

To show the induction principle, let P \subseteq \mathbb {N} such that 0 \in P and for any x \in \mathbb {N}, x \in P implies that s(x) \in P. Note that the hypothesis implies that P is inductive. Thus, \mathbb {N} \subseteq P by construction. Then by extensionality, \mathbb {N} = P.

It remains to show that s is injective. Let n,m \in \mathbb {N}. Suppose that s(n) = s(m). Then by definition n \cup {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}} = m \cup {\mathopen {}\{m\}\mathclose {}}. Since n \in n \cup {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}, n \in m \cup {\mathopen {}\{m\}\mathclose {}}. By union, n \in {\mathopen {}\{m\}\mathclose {}} or n \in m. In the former case, n = m by . In the latter case, we have s(n) \in s(m) by . But this means that we have s(n) \in s(m) = s(n), which contradicts .
A set X is well-ordered by a linear order \preceq \subseteq X \times X if every non-empty subset of X has a \preceq -least element.
The relation \leq defined by a \leq b \Leftrightarrow a \in s(b) is a well order on \mathbb {N}.

By induction, one can show that \leq is reflexive, transitive, and linear. It remains to show that \leq is a well order. To this end, let X \subseteq \mathbb {N} be a non-empty subset. Assume that X has no least elements. Consider P := {\mathopen {}\{x \in \mathbb {N}\colon \forall m \leq x.\mkern 5mum \notin X\}\mathclose {}}. Note that \varnothing \notin X since it would be a least element of X. Hence, 0 \in P.

Now, suppose that x \in P, i.e.,  orall m \leq x.\mkern 5mum 
otin X. We need to show that s(x) \in P, i.e.,  orall m \leq s(x).\mkern 5mum 
otin X. Let m \leq s(x). By definition, we have m \in s(x) or m = s(x). The latter case can be ruled out since it would be the least element of X. In the former case, we have m \leq x. Thus, m 
otin X follows from the hypothesis.
Since P = \mathbb {N}, this shows that X = \varnothing , which contradicts the assumption that X is a non-empty set.
Let < be a strict linear order on X. The initial segment of x \in X is the set \mathsf {IS}_{<}(x) := {\mathopen {}\{x' \in X\colon x' < x\}\mathclose {}}.

Let < be a strict linear order on X. Then X exhibits <-induction if for any subset P \subseteq X such that \forall x \in X.\mkern 5mu\mathsf {IS}_{<}(x) \subseteq P \Rightarrow x \in P, we have P = X.
Let < be a strict linear order on X. Then < exhibits well-founded induction if and only if < is a well order.

We show that for every x \in X, every subset A \subseteq X such that x \in A has a minimum. By <-induction, it suffices to show that if every x' \in \mathsf {IS}_{<}(x) has this property then so does x. Fix a subset A \subseteq X such that x \in A. If none of the x' \in \mathsf {IS}_{<}(x) is in A, then x is the least element. If some x' \in \mathsf {IS}_{<}(x), then A has a minimum by hypothesis.

Let P be any subset such that \forall x \in X.\mkern 5muP \subseteq \mathsf {IS}_{<}(x) \Rightarrow x \in P. Consider the minimum m \in X. Note that \mathsf {IS}_{<}(m) = \varnothing , so the hypothesis is equivalent to \forall x \in X.\mkern 5mux \in P, i.e., P = X.

In the base case, there is one choice: we set f_{0} = {\mathopen {}\{(0,x_{0})\}\mathclose {}}. Now, suppose that f_{n} exists uniquely. We define f_{s(n)} by f_{s(n)}(m) = \begin {cases} F(f_{n}(n)) & \text {if $m = s(n)$,}\\ f_{n}(m) & \text {if $m \leq n$.} \end {cases} It is clear by and the required equations that f_{s(n)} is the unique s(n)-germ and moreover f_{s(n)} extends f_{n}.

Since each n-germ exists uniquely, the following formula is a definable mapping: G(n,g) := (n \in \mathbb {N} \Rightarrow g = f_{n}) \wedge (n \notin \mathbb {N} \Rightarrow g = \varnothing ). By replacement, {\mathopen {}\{G(n)\colon n \in \mathbb {N}\}\mathclose {}} is a set. Then f := \bigcup {\mathopen {}\{G(n)\colon n \in \mathbb {N}\}\mathclose {}} is the required function.
If we are given a set X and a function h\colon X\to X in place of F. Then the same argument goes through. In particular, separation suffices in the last step.

Let X be a set equipped with a strict well-order and F be a binary definable mapping. Then there is a function f with domain X such that F(x,f{\upharpoonright }x) = f(x), where f{\upharpoonright }x := {\mathopen {}\{(x',z) \in f\colon x' < x\}\mathclose {}}.

We approximate f by means of x-germs. For x \in X, an x-germ is a function f_{x} with domain \mathsf {IS}_{<}(x) \cup {\mathopen {}\{x\}\mathclose {}} such that f_{x}(x') = F(x',f_{x}{\upharpoonright }x') for all x' \in \mathsf {dom}(f_{x}).
By , (X,<) admits <-induction. Then we use induction to show that each x-germ exists uniquely. The rest of the argument is analogous to .
We fix \mathbb {Z} := {{(\mathbb {N} \times \mathbb {N})}_{/{\sim }}} where (a,b) \sim (c,d) if and only if a + d = b + c.
We fix \mathbb {Q} := {{(\mathbb {Z} \times \mathbb {Z}^{+})}_{/{\sim }}} where (a,b) \sim (c,d) if and only if ad = bc.
For any two rational numbers p,q \in \mathbb {Q} such that p < q, there is a rational number r such that p < r < q.

A Dedekind real number is a subset r \subseteq \mathbb {Q} with the following properties.
\varnothing \subset r \subset \mathbb {Q}.
Left closed: If p \in r and q \in \mathbb {Q} such that q < p then q \in r.
No maximum: If p \in r then there is q \in r with p < q.
We fix \mathbb {R} := {\mathopen {}\{r \subseteq \mathbb {Q}\colon \text {$r$ is a Dedekind real}\}\mathclose {}}.

fr:ul.fr:li: r + s := {\mathopen {}\{p + q\colon p \in r, q \in s\}\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A \subseteq \mathbb {R} be a non-empty subset with an upper bound b \in \mathbb {R}. Then A has a supremum in \mathbb {R}.
There is no surjection f\colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {R}.
Let F be a family of non-empty sets. Then there is a choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F such that c(x) \in x for all x \in F.
Assuming AC, every surjection is a retraction.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let f\colon A\to B be a surjection. Consider the family F := {\mathopen {}\{f^{-1}(b)\colon b \in B\}\mathclose {}}. Note that this is a family of non-empty sets since f is a surjection. Then AC gives a choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F. Note that \bigcup F = A. Then we define i\colon B\to A by i(b) := c(f^{-1}(b)). It is routine to verify that it is the required injection.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The following statements are equivalent to the axiom of choice.

fr:ol.fr:li: Let I be a set and A be a function with \mathsf {dom}(A) = I such that A_{i} \neq \varnothing for all i \in I. Then there is a function c\colon I\to \bigcup _{i \in I}A_{i} such that c(i) \in A_{i} for all i \in I.
For any non-empty set A, there is a choice function c\colon \mathcal {P}(A) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\to A such that c(x) \in x for all non-empty x \subseteq A.
For any family F of non-empty and pairwise disjoint sets, there is a choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F such that c(x) \in x for all x \in F.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: AC implies (1): .

(1) implies (2): Given an index set I and a function A with \mathsf {dom}(I). Consider the function A' defined by A'_{i} = (A_{i},i). Note that there is an evident surjection r\colon \bigcup _{i \in I}A'_{i}\to I that maps each (A_{i},i) to the index i. This surjection admits a section s\colon I\to \bigcup _{i \in I}A'_{i}. Then we can define the required choice function c\colon I\to \bigcup _{i \in I}A_{i} by c(i) = \pi _{1} \circ s(i).

(2) implies (3): Let A be a non-empty set. Set I := \mathcal {P}(A) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}. Consider the identity function B_{i} := i. Then there is a choice function c\colon \mathcal {P}(A) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\to \bigcup _{i \in I} B_{i}. Note that \bigcup _{i \in I} B_{i} = A so this is the required choice function.

(3) implies (4): Let F be a family of non-empty and pairwise disjoint family of sets. Observe that F \subseteq \mathcal {P}(\bigcup F) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}. Thus, we can acquire the required choice function by restricting the choice function c\colon \mathcal {P}(\bigcup F) \setminus {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\to \bigcup F.

(4) implies AC: Let F be a family of non-empty sets. Consider the family F' := {\mathopen {}\{A \times {\mathopen {}\{A\}\mathclose {}}\colon A \in F\}\mathclose {}}. By replacement, this is a set. In particular, it consists of non-empty and pairwise disjoint sets. Thus, there is a choice function c'\colon F'\to \bigcup F'. Then we define the required choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F by c(A) = \pi _{1} \circ c'(A \times {\mathopen {}\{A\}\mathclose {}}).
Every set can be well ordered.
Let \preceq \subseteq X \times X be a partial order. A subset Y \subseteq X is a \preceq -chain if \preceq is total on Y.
Let \preceq be a partial order on X. If every \preceq -chain has an upper bound in X, then X has a maximal element, i.e., there is an element m \in X such that m \nprec x for all x \in X.
The following statements are equivalent.

fr:ol.fr:li: Every set X can be assigned a cardinality |X|.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1) implies (2): Let X be a set. Consider the set W := {\mathopen {}\{R \subseteq X \times X\colon \text {$R$ well orders $\mathsf {supp}(R)$}\}\mathclose {}}. We define a partial order \sqsubseteq by R \sqsubseteq R' if and only if R \subseteq R' and for all x \in \mathsf {supp}(R) and y \in \mathsf {supp}(R') \setminus \mathsf {supp}(R), (x,y) \in R'. For any \sqsubseteq -chain C, note that \bigcup C is an upper bound. Then, the maximal element is what we seek.

(2) implies (3): Let F be a family of non-empty sets. Since every set can be well-ordered, we define the required choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F by mapping each A \in F to its minimum element.

(3) implies (1): Let (X,\preceq ) be a chain-closed partial order. Suppose that (X,\preceq ) does not have a maximal element. Then every chain Y has a strict upper bound y. Thus, there is a choice function c that maps each chain Y to a chosen upper bound. By Hartog's theorem, there is an ordinal \alpha such that \alpha \npreceq X. Now, consider the recursive function i with domain \alpha defined by i(\beta ) = \begin {cases} c(\mathsf {ran}(i{\upharpoonright }\beta )) & \text {if $\mathsf {ran}(i{\upharpoonright }\beta )$ is a chain,}\\ \varnothing & \text {otherwise.} \end {cases} By induction on \beta , one can verify that i is an injection into X, yielding a contradiction.
(2) implies (4): Any set X can be well ordered. Then consider \mathsf {Ord}(X,<). By , \mathsf {Ord}(X,<) \approx \alpha for some initial \alpha .
(4) implies (2): Given a set X, consider its cardinality |X|. Then we can define a well order on X by transporting the well order on |X| via any bijection witnessing |X| \approx X.
Assuming Zorn's lemma, for any two sets A,B, there is either an injection A \to B or there is an injection B \to A.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Consider the set W := {\mathopen {}\{f \subseteq A \times B\colon \text {$f$ is a injection}\}\mathclose {}}. Note that the usual \subseteq relation partially orders W. For any chain C, \bigcup C is an upper bound. Thus, there is an maximal element f. If \mathsf {dom}(f) = A, then we are done. If not, then \mathsf {cod}(f) = B, so we can reverse the mapping to get an injection from B to A.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A set A is at least as numerous as B, written A \preceq B, if there is an injection A \rightarrowtail B. A, B are equinumerous, written A \approx B, if there is a bijection from A to B.
A set X is finite if there is a natural number n such that n \approx X. A set is infinite if it is not finite.
If A is at least as numerous as B and vice-versa, then A \approx B.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to A be injections. Consider the composite \varphi := \mathcal {P}(A) \xrightarrow {f_{!}} \mathcal {P}(B) \xrightarrow {\lnot _{B}} \mathcal {P}(B) \xrightarrow {g_{!}} \mathcal {P}(A) \xrightarrow {\lnot _{A}} \mathcal {P}(A) By Knaster-Tarski fixed-point theorem, \varphi has a fixed point C. Now define h(a) = \begin {cases} f(a) & \text {if $a \in C$,}\\ g^{-1}(a) & \text {otherwise.} \end {cases} This is the required bijection.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \alpha be an ordinal. Then for any \beta \in \alpha
\beta = \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ).
\beta is an ordinal.

Let \gamma \in \beta . Transitivity in \alpha implies that \gamma \in \alpha . Thus, \gamma \in \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ). Conversely, assume that \gamma \in \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ), then \gamma \in \beta by definition. Thus, extensionality gives \beta = \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ).

Transitivity in \alpha implies that \beta \subseteq \alpha . Thus, (\beta ,\in ) is a well order. It remains to show that \beta is transitive. To this end, suppose that \delta \in \gamma \in \beta . Then since \beta = \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ), we have \delta \in \beta .
If \alpha is an ordinal, then so is \alpha {^{+}} := \alpha \cup {\mathopen {}\{\alpha \}\mathclose {}}.
Let A be a set of ordinals. Then \bigcup A is an ordinal.
Let A be a set of ordinals. A is an ordinal if and only if A is transitive.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It suffices to show the only if direction. Suppose that A is transitive. Then observe that A = \bigcup {\mathopen {}\{\alpha {^{+}}\colon \alpha \in A\}\mathclose {}} is an ordinal by and .

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any two ordinals \alpha ,\beta , \alpha \in \beta , \alpha = \beta , or \beta \in \alpha .

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Note that \alpha ,\beta \in \alpha {^{+}} \cup \beta {^{+}}. The latter is an ordinal by and , so linearity yields the thesis.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An ordinal \alpha is a successor ordinal if there is some ordinal \beta such that \alpha = \beta {^{+}}. It is a limit ordinal if for all \beta \in \alpha one has \beta {^{+}} \in \alpha .
Let \alpha be an ordinal. Then \alpha is either a successor ordinal or a limit ordinal.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose that there is some \beta \in \alpha such that \beta {^{+}} = \alpha . In this case, we are done. Suppose the contrary. By , we have \alpha \in \beta {^{+}}, \alpha = \beta {^{+}} or \beta {^{+}} \in \alpha . The first case contradicts foundation and the second case contradicts the hypothesis, so they can be ruled out.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any strict well order (X,<), there is an ordinal \mathsf {Ord}(X,<) that is order isomorphic to (X,<).

By the recursion scheme (), we can define a function f with domain X as follows: f(x) = \mathsf {ran}(f{\upharpoonright }x) We take \mathsf {ran}(f) to be the underlying set of \mathsf {Ord}(X,<). As an example, consider X = \mathbb {N} equipped with the usual ordering <. In this case, f is the usual von Neumann encoding of natural numbers: f(0) = \varnothing , f(1) = {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}, f(2) = {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing , {\mathopen {}\{\varnothing \}\mathclose {}}\}\mathclose {}}, and so on.
It is routine to verify that (\mathsf {ran}(f),\in ) is an ordinal and f is an order isomorphism.
Isomorphic ordinals have the same underlying set.
Let \alpha ,\beta be two isomorphic ordinals and f\colon \alpha \to \beta be an order isomorphism witnessing \alpha \cong \beta . By induction, we show that f(a) = a.

Let a \in \alpha , suppose that for all a' \in \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(a), we have f(a') = a'. By , f(a) = {\mathopen {}\{b\colon b \in f(a)\}\mathclose {}}. Since f is an order isomorphism, we have f(a) = {\mathopen {}\{f(a')\colon a' \in a\}\mathclose {}}. Then the induction hypothesis gives f(a) = a.
For any set X, there is an ordinal \alpha such that \alpha \npreceq X.

Consider the set \alpha := {\mathopen {}\{\mathsf {Ord}(\mathsf {supp}(R),R)\colon R \in W\}\mathclose {}}, where W := {\mathopen {}\{R \subseteq X \times X\colon \text {$R$ well orders its support}\}\mathclose {}}. \alpha is a set by replacement. It is routine to check that \alpha is transitive, so by , \alpha is an ordinal. Indeed, \alpha consists of ordinals \beta such that \beta \preceq X. Thus, if \alpha \preceq X, then we have \alpha \in \alpha , contradicting foundation.
An ordinal \alpha is initial if for all \beta \in \alpha , we have \beta \prec \alpha .
The ordinal \omega := \mathsf {Ord}(\mathbb {N},<) is an initial ordinal.
For every ordinal \alpha , there is a unique initial ordinal \beta such that \alpha \approx \beta .
Consider the subset B = {\mathopen {}\{\gamma \in \alpha {^{+}}\colon \gamma \approx \alpha \}\mathclose {}}. Note that this is a non-empty subset, so it has a minimum \beta .

Let \gamma \in \beta , then the inclusion \gamma \subseteq \beta yields \gamma \preceq \beta . It remains to rule out \gamma \approx \beta . Suppose that \gamma \approx \beta , then we have \gamma \approx \beta \approx \alpha . This means that \gamma \in B, so \beta \in \gamma , but this contradicts foundation since we would have \beta \in \gamma \in \beta in this case.

Suppose that \gamma is an initial ordinal such that \alpha \approx \gamma . By , there are three cases \gamma \in \beta , \alpha = \beta , and \beta \in \gamma . The first and the last cases can be ruled out since initiality implies \alpha \approx \gamma \prec \beta and \alpha \approx \beta \prec \gamma these respective cases.

Let \alpha be an ordinal. The Aleph number \aleph _{\alpha } is defined by transfinite recursion as follows:
\aleph _{0} := \omega ;
\aleph _{\beta {^{+}}} := \text {the least initial ordinal $\alpha $ such that $\aleph _{\beta } \prec \alpha $}.
\aleph _{\lambda } := \bigcup {\mathopen {}\{\aleph _{\gamma }\colon \gamma \in \lambda \}\mathclose {}}, where \gamma is a limit ordinal.
For any infinite and initial ordinal \alpha , there is an ordinal \beta such that \alpha = \aleph _{\beta }.
Let X be a set. Its cardinality |X| is any initial ordinal \alpha such that \alpha \approx X.
For any ordinal \alpha , 2^{\aleph _{\alpha }} = \aleph _{\alpha + 1}.
